title: First look inside back of 'frozen coffin' lorry where 39 migrants were found dead
text:

This is the first glimpse inside the back of a refrigerated trailer where 39 migrants -all said to be Chinese nationals - were found dead.

It is feared the victims died in an icy tomb in the container where temperatures can get as low as -25C.

It is believed the victims had been in the container for more than 12 hours.

Police probing one of the UK's biggest murder inquiries continue to quiz a suspect, named locally as 25-year-old Mo Robinson, who was arrested on suspicion of murder.

Officers in Northern Ireland have raided three properties believed to be linked to the arrest in Grays, Essex.

Have you been affected by the incident? Email webnews@mirror.co.uk.

Sources told the Telegraph it is "very unlikely" Robinson, from Portadown, knew about any alleged plans to smuggle migrants into the UK.

Police were investigating a suspected Irish people-smuggling ring, the report claimed.

Robinson's girlfriend, a hairdresser, is said to be pregnant with twins.

Robinson's parents, who live in Laurelvale in Co Armagh, have flown to England to support him, a neighbour the Belfast Telegraph.

(Image: REUTERS)

His father is the manager of Laurelvale FC, a local amateur club in the Mid-Ulster Football League.

Paul Berry, a local unionist councillor, said he spoke to Robinson's dad, Mark, "a couple of times" on Wednesday, but by that point it appeared the family hadn't been told of the arrest.

Mr Berry added: "When I was talking to him nothing had been confirmed to him that it was Mo. The police or nobody of that nature had informed him."

He stressed Mo Robinson was "innocent until proven guilty".

It is believed Robinson picked up the trailer two hours before the migrants were found dead.

Temperatures in the refrigerated container get as low as -25C.

The trailer had entered England via a freight ferry service from Zeebrugge, Belgium, into Purfleet, Essex, on the River Thames.

Belgian authorities said the container arrived at Zeebrugge at 2.49pm local time on Tuesday and left the Belgian port the same afternoon.

(Image: PA)

The ferry docked in Essex just after 12.30am on Wednesday and the lorry left the port in Purfleet about 35 minutes later.

The tractor that hauled it away from the port had come from from Northern Ireland, according to police.

It had "Ireland" emblazoned on the windscreen along with the message "The Ultimate Dream".

The Bulgarian ministry of foreign affairs said the truck was registered in Varna in Bulgaria "under the name of a company owned by an Irish citizen".

Paramedics were alerted first after the bodies were discovered and Essex Police were notified just after 1.40am.

(Image: REUTERS)

The migrants were found dead in the trailer at the Waterglade Industrial Park in Grays.

British authorities are now trying to identify the 39 people who died.

The lorry was moved to nearby Tilbury Docks so the bodies can be recovered while preserving the dignity of the victims.

Belgium's federal prosecutor's office has launched its own investigation to find out where the trailer originated and how long it had been in the country.

The office said it is not yet clear when or where the victims entered the container.

C.RO Ports, which manages the ferry terminals in Zeebrugge and Purfleet said it was "deeply saddened" and assisting investigators.

The incident follows warnings from the National Crime Agency and the Border Force of the increased risk of people-smuggling via Belgium.

Security checks for people smuggling are believed to be less stringent at both ports than at Calais and Dover.
description: The 39 bodies were found in a lorry trailer in Grays, Essex, and it is feared they died in an icy tomb as temperatures in the container can get as low as -25C
